You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in this context, governing council will remain cautious with respect to future policy adjustments, guided by incoming data.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: us inflation looks to have resumed its downward path.\n                "}]

   \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: wage growth remains moderate, although it is projected to pick up in the coming quarters, consistent with the bank’s latest business outlook survey.\n                "}]

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: near-term inflation expectations have moved up, but longer-run expectations remain anchored on the 2% target.\n                "}]

Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: canada’s economic growth in the second quarter was stronger than expected, and was more broad-based across regions and sectors.\n                "}]

changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: after a contraction of 2 ½ percent in 2020, the bank now projects global gdp to grow by just over 6 ¾ percent in 2021, about 4 percent in 2022, and almost 3 ½ percent in 2023.\n                "}]

reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation is picking up following a weak 2023.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence simply reports on the growth trend in the euro area without implying any policy action or stance by the Bank of Canada."
}

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the two main downside    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: total cpi inflation in canada has been around 1 per cent in recent months, reflecting year-over-year price declines for consumer energy products.\n                "}]

Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the bank’s projection, this happens sometime in the middle quarters of 2022.\n                "}]

Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: ongoing uncertainty related to trade conflicts has undermined business sentiment and activity, contributing to a synchronous slowdown across many countries.\n                "}]

changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, lower prices for oil and other commodities since the summer have further lowered canada’s terms of trade and are dampening business investment and exports in the resource sector.\n                "}]

reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of
