changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the bank expects inflation will stay around the 2 percent target over the projection horizon, with some fluctuations in 2020 from volatility in energy prices.\n                "}]

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the canadian economy continues to operate close to its potential and the composition of growth is more balanced.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence describes the economy's current state without implying any policy action or bias, simply stating that it is operating close to its potential with a more balanced growth composition."

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: as governing council continues to monitor incoming data, it will pay particular attention to developments in the energy sector and the impact of trade conflicts on the prospects for canadian growth and inflation.\n of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: at that time, the governing council will consider exiting the reinvestment phase and reducing the size of its balance sheet by allowing roll-off of maturing government of canada bonds.\n                "}]

}

action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: canada’s weaker terms of Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: overall, the bank judges the risks to the canadian inflation outlook are roughly balanced over the projection horizon.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence provides a neutral assessment of the inflation outlook, stating that the risks are balanced, without implying any specific policy action or bias."
}

Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: some progress has been made on the key issues being watched closely by governing council, particularly the dynamics of inflation and wage growth.\n                "}]

reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the context of a projection that is largely unchanged, the bank’s governing council judges that the current stance of monetary policy is still appropriate and maintains the target for the overnight rate at 1/2 per Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: we will continue to evaluate the appropriate degree of monetary policy accommodation as new data arrive.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence implies a wait-and-see approach, without leaning towards tightening or easing, and does not provide any explicit indication of a change in monetary policy stance."
}

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: china’s economy is showing label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: to support the recovery and achieve the inflation objective, the bank is prepared to provide further monetary stimulus as needed.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that the Bank of Canada is willing to provide additional monetary stimulus to support the recovery and achieve the inflation objective, indicating an accommodative stance."
}

overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, price pressures remain broadly based, with two-thirds of cpi components increasing more than 5% over the past year.\n                "}]

action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the bank is neutral with Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without
